title: 107_hr2206
content: The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2001, also known as the "Energy Efficiency Investment Act," introduces a credit for energy-efficient property in residences and businesses under section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2001, also known as the "Energy Efficiency Investment Act," allows a 25 percent tax credit for qualified energy property placed in service during the taxable year. Qualified energy property includes energy-efficient building components and heating/cooling equipment that are Energy Star qualified. The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2001 offers a 25 percent tax credit for qualified energy property used as the taxpayer's principal residence, with original use starting with the taxpayer and a useful life of at least 5 years. Definitions include "building envelope component," "principal residence," and "Energy Star qualified." The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2001 provides a 25 percent tax credit for qualified energy property used as the taxpayer's principal residence. The property must meet Energy Star guidelines and display the Energy Star label at the time of installation. The tax credit is limited based on the amount of tax liability for the taxable year. The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2001 offers a 25 percent tax credit for qualified energy property in the taxpayer's principal residence. The credit is limited by the tax liability for the year and any excess can be carried over to the next year. Special rules apply for tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations. The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2001 provides a 25 percent tax credit for qualified energy property in the taxpayer's principal residence. Special rules apply for individuals who are members of a condominium management association with respect to a condominium they own, allowing them to claim a proportionate share of expenditures for qualified energy property. The term 'condominium management association' refers to an organization meeting specific requirements for a condominium project where most units are used as residences. Expenditures for labor related to qualified energy property are included. In cases where less than 80 percent of the property is used for nonbusiness purposes, only that portion of the expenditure is eligible for tax credit. For nonbusiness purposes, only the portion of the expenditure properly allocable to use for nonbusiness purposes is eligible for the tax credit. If a credit is allowed for an expenditure on qualified energy property, the basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit. This provision applies to qualified energy property placed in service or installed on or after January 1, 2001. The tax credit for qualified energy property applies to nonbusiness purposes, with the basis of the property reduced by the amount of the credit. A new paragraph is added to the code regarding the credit allowed under section 30B. The tax credit for qualified energy property applies to nonbusiness purposes, with the basis of the property reduced by the amount of the credit. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2001.
